info.title: Aether
info.description: The bundle is a combination of account and payment products. This is a single API call that calls the underlying APIs to issue accounts and payment instruments to account holders. Each tenant partner is given bundle IDs that can be used by them to issue bundles to account holders.

tags.name: Repair Service
tags.description: Aether Repair APIs

tags.name: Bundle status v3
tags.description: APIs related to the Bundle Status and its configuration - v3 version

put.summary: Manually update a bundle status. This endpoint is a request to manually update the status of a specific bundle. Using this endpoint, you can only update the manual and derived manual bundle statuses. Statuses that can be manually applied on the bundle are called manual bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived due to a manual action on any entity, like an account or account holder, are called derived manual bundle statuses. For example, if your fraud and risk monitoring team suspects that a customer's account has been compromised, you could use this endpoint to temporarily disable the customer's ability to make transactions by applying a relevant bundle status.
put.description: Manually update a bundle status. This endpoint is a request to manually update the status of a specific bundle. Using this endpoint, you can only update the manual and derived manual bundle statuses. Statuses that can be manually applied on the bundle are called manual bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived due to a manual action on any entity, like an account or account holder, are called derived manual bundle statuses. For example, if your fraud and risk monitoring team suspects that a customer's account has been compromised, you could use this endpoint to temporarily disable the customer's ability to make transactions by applying a relevant bundle status.

parameters.description: This is the unique identification code (ID) of the bundle.

parameters.name: bundleStatusModelCode
parameters.description: This is the unique identification code of the bundle status model. Statuses that can be manually applied on the bundle are called manual bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived by the system and applied on bundles based on predefined rules, are called auto bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived due to a manual action on any entity, like an account or account holder, are called derived manual bundle statuses.

put.description: This event occurs whenever the status of a bundle is updated manually. It confirms that the new bundle status has been applied successfully.
This event occurs whenever the override is applied manually on the bundle statuses. It confirms that the new bundle status has been applied successfully.

isPermanent.description: This indicates whether the status applied on a bundle is permanent or not. If the value is set to true, the bundle status is permanent. If the value is set to false, the bundle status is not permanent.

priority.description: This is the priority of the status applied on a bundle.

effectiveFrom.description: This is the system date from when the bundle status is effective. If the grace days are greater than zero, then the effectiveFrom is calculated as system date + grace days + 1. It is effective from midnight. If the grace days are equal to zero, then the effectiveFrom is the current system date.

policyVersionID.description: Used for versioning of a transaction policy, the version gets updated each time a policy is updated. policyVersionId is used to identify the version

action.description: This is the action that triggers the policy enforcement. This action is one of the types of posting.

minRequiredBalance.description: This is the minimum balance that should be available after the posting is done. If the balance available after the posting would be lesser than the minimum required balance, then this policy is violated and the appropriate policy violation action is taken.

maxAllowedBalance.description: This is the maximum balance that is allowed after a posting is done. If the balance available after the posting would be greater than the maximum allowed balance, then this policy is violated and the appropriate policy violation action is taken.

minRequiredBalanceBeforeTxn.description: This is the minimum balance that should be available before a transaction takes place. If the balance available before the transaction takes place is lesser than the  mimimum balance required before the transaction, then this transaction policy is violated and the appropriate policy violation action is taken.

maxAllowedBalanceBeforeTxn.description: This is the maximum balance that can be available before a transaction takes place. If the balance available before a transaction takes place is greater than the maximum balance allowed after the transaction, then this transaction policy is violated and the appropriate policy violation action is taken.

transactionCategory.description: The Transaction Category code associated with this policy

errorCode.description: This is the error code of the transaction policy.

PolicyBalanceRule.description: This contains details of the policy balance rules.

code.description:
This is the code name of the resource product. Its format is `XXXCCYYNNNN[N]`. The guidelines for the naming convention are as follows: * XXX: The first three characters represent an entity type. For example, RSP represents a resource product.
The first alphabet can't be O, X, Y, or Z characters. These characters are reserved to accommodate future changes, including code naming conventions. * CC: These two characters represent the country code to which the entity belongs. The code is as per the ISO 3166-1 standard. It's ZZ for objects that aren't specific to any country. * YY: These two characters indicate if an entity is system provided or customer created. ZZ indicate that the entity is system provided. Any other value means that it's a customer created entity.
This is currently set to 00 (zero). These characters are reserved to accommodate future changes. * NNNN[N]: The last four or five characters depict a unique code for each entity.

EmptyClass.description:
This object lists down all the necessary configurations of a reservoir. A reservoir is a storage system where the CMS keeps precreated cards associated with an SKU. It reduces the time it takes to associate a card with a user when a card request is received. It has the following main fields:

1. inventory.size - It determines the maximum number of precreated cards that are available against the SKU in the reservoir.

2. refill.enabled - It determines whether to refill the reservoir or not.
3. refilling.rate -  It determines the maximum number of cards that can be demanded for one refill cycle. One cycle is one iteration of publishing demand for the cards. A day consists of 24 cycles, and you have the flexibility to configure the number of cycles per day.
4. issuances.enabled - It determines whether the cards are to be issued from the reservoir or not.
5. reservoir.enabled - It determines whether the reservoir is enabled or not for the SKU.

bundleID.description: This is the unique identification code (ID) of the bundle.

bundleStatus.description: This is the unique identification code (ID) of the bundle status.

name.description: This is the name of the bundle status.

description.description: This is a description of the bundle status.

type.description: This is the unique identification code of the bundle status model. Statuses that can be manually applied on the bundle are called manual bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived by the system and applied on bundles based on predefined rules, are called auto bundle statuses. Statuses that are derived due to a manual action on any entity, like an account or account holder, are called derived manual bundle statuses.

isPermanent.description: This indicates whether the status applied on a bundle is permanent or not. If the value is set to true, the bundle status is permanent. If the value is set to false, the bundle status is not permanent.

priority.description: This is the priority of the status applied on a bundle.

graceDays.description: This is the number of days after status change when restrictions are applied on a bundle.

effectiveFrom.description: This is the system date from when the bundle status is effective. If the grace days are greater than zero, the effectiveFrom is calculated as system date + grace days + 1. It is effective from midnight. If the grace days are equal to zero, the effectiveFrom is the current system date.

effectiveFromBookDates.description: This is a list of book dates for the account provider management systems (APMS) and their products.

remarks.description: This provides additional information related to the bundle status.

reasonCode.description: This is the reason for the current bundle status.

reasonCodeDescription.description: This is a description of the reason code.

restrictedActions.description: This is a list of restrictions applied on the accounts.

originalEffectiveFrom.description: This is the original effective from date of the bundle status.

originalEffectiveFromBookDates.description: This is a list of original effective from book dates.

overrideDays.description: This is the number of days the status is overridden for.

overrideStartDate.description: This is the date from which the status is overridden.
